description: Skull, heavy, hammered and soldered silver work. A solder line bisects the skull vertically, parallel to the face. The incised lines representing sutures are independent of the solder line. Insets in the eye-sockets were once filled with inlaid stones or shells.
text: Included in a 1944 Wadsworth Athenaeum exhibition called “Ancient Peruvian Art,” the skull was originally attributed to the Chimú and dated to the fifth or sixth century. However, it is most likely a 20th-century work inspired by ancient Andean metalwork and crafted to meet a demand for such ancient works that began in the 1930s. There is a long tradition of skull-shaped vessels in ancient Andean art, and such works have always been popular with collectors.
title: Figure of a Skull
